Maybe using [ViewStub](http://developer.android.com/reference/android/view/ViewStub.html)
Wrong, `ViewStub` is `final`...

`ViewStub` still seems to be the best bet.

PDF would then be loaded into it using:

``` java
View pdfView = PDFView.get(this, R.id.viewStubId)
    .loadAsset(pdfName)
    ...
    .load();
```

This would allow me to switch the implementation, inflating either a `SurfaceView` or a `TextureView` depending on the OS version.

---

**NOTE!** ViewStub can't be inflated twice. I can prevent double inflation by using the `ViewStub`'s id as the id of the view i'll create, using [setInflatedId()](http://developer.android.com/reference/android/view/ViewStub.html#setInflatedId(int\)). Then I just need to check if the `ViewStub` has been instantiated already.

This problem is due to the maven eclipse plugin missing a configurator for some newly introduced task in the `android-maven-plugin`.

You can tell m2e to ignore this task by adding this to your main pom 

``` xml
 <pluginManagement>
     <plugins>
      <plugin>
       <groupId>org.eclipse.m2e</groupId>
        <artifactId>lifecycle-mapping</artifactId>
         <version>1.0.0</version>
       <configuration>
        <lifecycleMappingMetadata>
          <pluginExecutions>
           <pluginExecution>
            <pluginExecutionFilter>
              <groupId>com.jayway.maven.plugins.android.generation2</groupId>
             <artifactId>android-maven-plugin</artifactId>
             <versionRange>[1.0.0,)</versionRange>
              <goals>
               <goal>consume-aar</goal>
              </goals>
             </pluginExecutionFilter>
            <action>
             <ignore />
            </pluginExecution>
           </action>
           </pluginExecutions>
          </lifecycleMappingMetadata>
         </configuration>
       </plugin>
       . . . 
```

@ecstasy2 I think my comment on your PR is clear enough. You don't use NineOldAndroids in your PR so the animations will still crash on pre-honeycomb devices. Plus, you included NineOldAndroids as a jar file in `libs`, while it should be added in the `pom.xml` instead (and also the gradle build file now). The last thing is that in your PR you replaced `decodingAsyncTask.executeOnExecutor(AsyncTask.THREAD_POOL_EXECUTOR);` by `decodingAsyncTask.execute();` which is not the same thing => all started async tasks **need** to be executed on the **same** executor, otherwise the native vudroid decoding part will eventually crash. 

I'm sorry I have no time to work on this, but I'm ready to test PR if you submit one.

If you use 4 commits instead of one, you still have a commit that destroys completely the `AnimationManager` and recreates it, making it hard for anyone to trace when was each line modified the last time in the file, and making the git history unclear. What I would have wanted is you to merge your further commits into the first one, so that **only the concerned lines are modified**.

The PDFView class has a `.fromFile` method. 
Simply pass in your FileUri. If you look at the source of **[PDFView.java](https://github.com/JoanZapata/android-pdfview/blob/master/android-pdfview/src/main/java/com/joanzapata/pdfview/PDFView.java#L967)**,
the `.fromAsset` actually calls this method.

```
pdfView.fromFile(FileUri)
                    .defaultPage(1)
                    .swipeVertical(true)
                    .showMinimap(false)
                    .enableSwipe(true)
                    .load();
```
All the rendering is made using the [vudroid](https://code.google.com/p/vudroid/) library. If they don't provide it, neither does `pdfview`, sorry.

You can find official releases on [maven central](http://search.maven.org/#browse%7C-1653732968). What you need is the `.aar` or `.apklib` file depending on your build system.

The background of the PDF was hardcoded to white. I changed it. Now default is White but you can set a 
custom background color. With :

The internal method is called setBackgroundPDF and not setBackground or setBackgroundColor because they already exist in the class View and I didn't want to override them.

I'm sure someone can come up with a much better solution than that though.

I had this problem as well. I thought I had solved it by adding this line to my build.grade:
- `compile 'com.joanzapata.pdfview:android-pdfview:1.+@aar'`

It worked great in the simulator. Then when I installed it on a HUDL 2 it would crash every time with the java.lang.UnsatisfiedLinkError. The problem was that the HUDL 2 is x86_64 and android-pdfview doesn't include an x86_64 version of vudroid.so. That doesn't matter if no other dependencies have x86_64 libraries, as the 32 bit x86 libraries will be used instead. I did have a dependency that had x86_64 libraries, so no version of vudroid.so would be loaded. I could get rid of the other dependency as I wasn't using it anymore, then everything was ok.

A great tool for debugging this is Native Libs Monitor. Install that on your device and it will say what libraries have been loaded and are available in each app.

Can you please let me know what changes you made to resolve this issue?

I am using RxJava, an Observable and Subscription to create a new thread to load the pdf and extract its bitmap. The problem was that more than 1 call could be made to this method, so there could be more than one thread opening the pdf. I added flags to check for this in my code, I changed nothing in the lib. 
What problem are you experiencing?
